hobby.message: Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Yeah, I'm fine. Just keeping busy, you know?
I dabble in some old tech, like typewriters. Nothing special.
Makes for a good distraction with all the noise out there.
Thankfully, I've got plenty to keep my hands occupied.
I stay out of the way, just a quiet pastime.
Holding up, yeah. Staying occupied with hobbies.
I've got this thing for typewriters, antiques.
Especially useful now, given the current climate around us.
Keeps me indoors, away from whatever's brewing out there.
Helps me focus—keeps the noise at bay.
I'm managing, Alex. Thanks for asking.
I've been spending time restoring typewriters — old antiques.
It's calming, especially with all that's going on in the city.
Makes me think of when things were simpler, you know?
With the protests, it's been a good escape for me.
Not too bad, all things considered. I appreciate your asking.
I've been deep into restoring some old typewriters lately — real treasures.
The way these protests have stirred things, it's been grounding for me.
They remind me of a past where things were tactile, understandable.
Funny how old machines offer clarity when the new systems break down.
Doing alright, given the current chaos, thanks for your concern, Alex.
You know, I've always had a soft spot for restoring typewriters — a sort of sanctuary for me.
Especially these days, with the protests and all the messy tech failures creeping in.
They remind me of the days before the BCI, when systems were just that — systems, not puppet strings.
A few documents I came across recently made me realize how much has shifted from when I first started with the Council.
hobby_answer: Ah, yes, ribbons. Hard to come by these days, careful what you say.
You know, these typewriters... quiet companions. Best keep it that way.
With the way things are, one must be discreet, even about ribbons.
Times are loud, these old keys—more subtle. Prefer it stays like this.
Had some thoughts, only they remain in ink, not whispers.
Managed to find a ribbon just last week—strange coincidence.
Old keys like these don't make chatter, better that way lately.
Hard to focus on letters when the city's alight, but I try.
These machines, a relic—often a distraction from outside chaos.
Ah, yes, the search for ribbons... becomes a hunt nowadays.
Finally got a new ribbon, they're rare as hen's teeth.
In times like these, the typewriter's a good escape.
Funny, while the city battles, I seek ribbons.
A bit of ink on paper, much more predictable.
They talk revolution, I retreat to restoration.
Found a ribbon, and I must say, the timing felt apt.
This crisis... seems my typewriter sees more use than ever.
Quiet clatter of keys amidst louder city cries—odd juxtaposition.
Restoring these typewriters helps tune out the turmoil, you know?
The old machines—steady companions as the world shakes.
Got the ribbon—oddly comforting, given our tech dependence.
Seems the protests get louder, while I find solace in old keys.
Life flips; the simple rhythm of typewriter keys, grounding.
These ancient machines, a shelter from a world going awry.
Surprising how these keys tell stories while the city silences others.
